abstract: <jats:p>Telomere biology is associated with cancer initiation and prognosis. Collected data suggest that blood cell telomere length (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content>) can change over time, which may be related to development of common disorders, such as cardiovascular diseases and cancer. Recently, single nucleotide polymorphisms in the region of the human telomerase reverse transcriptase (<jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERT</jats:styled-content>)</jats:italic> gene were associated with various malignancies, including glioma, lung and urinary bladder cancer, and telomerase <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RNA</jats:styled-content> gene <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERC</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> genotypes were recently linked to <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content>. In the present study a hypothetical association between identified genotypes in <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERT</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERC</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> genes and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content> were investigated. We analyzed 21 polymorphisms, covering 90% of the genetic variance, in the <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERT</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> gene, two genetic variants in <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERC</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>, and relative <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content>(<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RTL</jats:styled-content>) at average age 50 and 60 in 959 individuals with repeated blood samples. Mean <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RTL</jats:styled-content> at age 60 was associated with four genetic variants of the <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERT</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> gene (rs2736100, rs2853672, rs2853677, and rs2853676), two of which reported to be associated with cancer risk. Two alleles (rs12696304, rs16847897) near the <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERC</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> gene were confirmed as also being associated with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">RTL</jats:styled-content> at age 60. Our data suggest that <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERT</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>h<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TERC</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> genotypes have an impact on <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content> of potential relevance and detectable first at higher ages, which gives us further insight to the complex regulation of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TL</jats:styled-content>. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:368–372, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

reference.article-title: Telomere length is associated to obesity parameters but with a gender difference
reference.author: Nordfjäll K

title: hTERT Cancer Risk Genotypes Are Associated With Telomere Length
